abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Hurricane Emergency
            Project in Honduras is deemed satisfactory with likely
            sustainability, negligible developmental impact, and
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and the borrower.
            The project was part of a larger package of assistance to
            Honduras in response to the ravages of Hurricane Mitch. The
            major factors affecting project implementation were the good
            financial and project management. Early Bank involvement,
            with a quick assessment of a country's macroeconomic
            situation, is needed to develop an effective emergency
            assistance project. Longer term concerns about disaster
            management preparedness and mitigation need to be address,
            but it is not effective to combine this with emergency
            support objectives. The existence of experienced operational
            staff in the Field office is fundamental.

5084362.trustfund:
TF021461-CAETF - HONDURAS' EXTERNAL
            DEBT SERVICE (NON IBRD/IDA)
5084362.majtheme: Economic management,Rural development,Urban development,Social protection and risk management,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Hurricane Emergency Project assists
            Honduras in maintaining macroeconomic stability by financing
            imports associated with rebuilding social and economic
            infrastructure and by re-establishing production levels. It
            is an integral part of a broader set of the International
            Development Association's (IDA) efforts to help
            Nicaragua respond to the effects of Hurricane Mitch. The
            project provides immediate, quick-disbursing credit to
            support the purchase of 1) construction materials and
            equipment as well as water, land and air transport vehicles,
            petroleum, and fuel products needed for rehabilitating
            physical infrastructure; 2) seeds, fertilizers, and
            agricultural equipment along with materials, machinery, and
            fuel needed to reestablish agricultural production; 3)
            medical supplies and equipment needed to replenish
            stockpiles in hospitals, health centers, health posts, and
            outreach programs; 4) school supplies and equipment for
            educational facilities that were damaged or destroyed; and
            5) machinery, spare parts, and equipment for commercial and
            industrial companies.
